title: Module 2 - sections
body: Module 2 contains four sections.
instruction: Click on each section to find out more.

_items.title: Survey design - an introduction
_items.body:
This section will introduce: ​

  • customer requirements and conceptualisations: how to develop clear concepts and definitions for your survey questions​

  • questionnaire design best practice: stages of questionnaire design and question design principles

_items.title: Questionnaire design
_items.body:
This section will highlight everything you need to consider in order to design and develop a robust questionnaire, including:

  • stages of questionnaire design
  • development and qualitative testing of questions
  • questionnaire design principles and best practice

_items.title: Methods and Modes
_items.body:
• in this section we will explain the different methods by which survey data may be collected when using a structured questionnaire (a questionnaire with standardised questions). 

  • there are various modes we can employ, and a number of factors that will influence the choice. When designing a survey, this is one of the most important decisions

_items.title: Quantitative testing approaches
_items.body:
This section gives an overview of the potential stages of quantitative evaluation and testing during survey development, such as:

  • feasibility testing (pre-testing)
  • pilot surveys
  • dress rehearsals

title: Introduction to Module 2: Survey development and testing
body:
Welcome to Module 2 of Data Collection Fundamentals.

 

This Module will begin to introduce how to design your data collection tool. Included in this module is:​

  • survey design​ - an introduction

  • questionnaire design

  • methods and Modes​

  • quantitative testing approaches​

​

This module will not cover:​

  • sample design and estimation - for training and guidance on this, please visit the Analysis Function website

title: New Component Title
body:
In this module, we covered:

  • an introduction to survey design - identifying requirements and conceptualisation 

  • questionnaire design – how to adhere to best practice to ensure you are getting the most out of the responses, with little burden on the respondent​

  • Methods and Modes - how to adopt the most appropriate mode for your research

  • Quantitative testing ​- identifying when your research would benefit from quantitative testing approaches

title: What do we mean by 'survey design'?
displayTitle: What do we mean by 'survey design'?
body:
A survey is a data collection tool consisting of a list of questions that a pre-defined population will answer. Surveys collect information on people's opinions, behaviours or knowledge. ​

Survey design covers the definition of all aspects of a survey, from the initial data requirements gathering, through to the analysis of the data.

title: Requirements and Conceptualisations
body:
Before beginning your survey development, ensure you have fully established your customer and user needs. The Respondent Centred Design Framework is a survey-specific framework which provides guidance on how to design with your user at the centre, reducing respondent burden. If you're designing a tool that isn't a survey, you can refer to the User Centred Design resources from Module 1. You can also use the 'Data requirements template' to help you gather data requirements. ​

Whilst we covered establishing customer and user needs in Module 1, there are also some survey-specific considerations to keep in mind. ​

For example, there may be pre-existing dependencies, for example, pre-collection processes such as sampling and post collection processes such as editing and imputation. It is therefore important at this stage to include all parties who may also have an interest in the data collection process as a whole. ​

If you're working on a questionnaire which already exists, you may come across customers who are concerned with the consistency of the data collected. By this, we mean placing too much focus on the questions which were asked previously (which may be flawed), rather than revisiting what they want to collect and potentially improving the questions by redesigning them. Differing needs can often arise at this stage, so making sure that all aims for the data are covered at this point is crucial.​

Furthermore, during the transition from paper to online collection mode, the researcher may have the opportunity to transform the existing questions to better suit the new mode. These changes make the survey easier to complete, reducing the respondent burden and potentially enhance data quality.

title: New Component Title
body:
Carrying out preliminary research can help to clarify concepts and definitions beyond the parameters considered by the customer. This research is used to inform the design of your survey questions. This can be carried out in one of several ways, including: ​

  • literature reviews​

  • consultation with subject matter experts and end users​

  • qualitative research methods such as focus groups or interviews (more detail on these in Module 3)​

Once this initial investigation has been completed researchers will be in a better position to agree a research framework with the customer. This will help meet the initial aim of the research, resulting in better quality data and more efficiently turned around projects. By agreeing requirements and definitions in advance we can be assured that there will be less need to complete several iterations of the same research piece, saving time and money.

title: New Component Title
body: There are two main types of survey questions by content:

_items.backBody: Factual questions include things like socio-demographic characteristics (for example age, marital status, housing tenure and economic activity), questions about behaviour and experiences, and questions about knowledge of a subject.
Attitudinal questions ask someone’s general feelings about a subject or their specific opinions.

title: New Component Title
body: The process of gathering requirements is often referred to as ‘Conceptualisation'.

_items.title: How do you develop concepts?
_items.body:
Concepts are developed by defining the key measures or target groups and by specifying which survey questions need to be asked to address the research question. It is through the development of clear and unambiguous concept definitions that we are able to produce robust and reliable data. These are things you should discuss with the customer in the requirements gathering stage.​

An example of this is outlined below. In this instance we are looking to measure income. In order to do this, we first need to determine what we mean by ‘income’. For example: ​

  ​

  • are we looking to measure income at the household or personal level?​

  • are we talking about salary, pensions, cash-in-hand work, benefits, profit made on shares?​

  • do you want information before or after tax?​

  • do you want monthly or annual figures?

title: New Component Title
body:
The objective of question design is to develop questions that every potential respondent will interpret in the way intended, be able to respond to accurately, and be willing to answer. A good question will produce answers which are:​

  • valid i.e. accurately reflect what it is we are trying to measure​

  • reliable i.e. when applied repeatedly to comparable populations it produces consistent findings

title: The stages of questionnaire design
body:
Once you have identified your requirements and conceptualisations, you can begin your questionnaire design. 

These stages are in order, according to best practice in questionnaire design.

_items.title: 1. Identify your respondents
_items.body:
List the types of people who will be answering your questionnaire. You can create personas (which are fictional, yet realistic, descriptions of a typical or target user) to do this. Personas group your users based on similar behaviours (for example, people who use your service for a similar purpose).​

Examples of different personas completing business surveys could be: ​

  • office managers/Book-keepers ​

  • individual company accountants ​

  • group accountants ​

Think of how each persona will navigate your questionnaire (that is, their journey through your questionnaire). Find out more about personas.

_items.title: 2. Consider Methods and Modes
_items.body:
You establish the methods and modes before designing any questions, as your questions will be dependent on the methods and modes used. 

We will cover this in more detail shortly in the course.

_items.title: 3. Consider question formats and design layout
_items.body:
Choosing the right question format and type of data is crucial to getting quality data from your responses. You must decide which format and response type will allow you to get data that achieves your research aims.​

There are two main formats: open and closed. ​

  • Open-ended questions allow the respondents to give an answer in their own words. An example is ‘Why did you leave your last paid job?’ ​

  • Closed-ended questions require respondents to choose their answers from a predetermined list of categories. For example, for the question ‘Are you currently employed?’, the response options could be:​

  1. Yes​

  2. No​

  3. Prefer not to say

title: New Component Title
body: Click on the boxes below to read more about each question format.

_items.backBody:
These types of questions can sometimes be used to inform the development of closed questions. ​Use if:​

  • you want to know the 'why'​

  • you want to gain opinions and in-depth responses​

  • you have an 'other' category when all response options are not known​

Would not use if:​

  • you require answers to a specific set of response items. ​

  • if you want respondents to make a choice between set options. ​

  • if you want to collect quantitative statistics, for example how many respondents choose option 1. ​

  • we already know what the options set should be and are not trying to discover these options.​

Example question: 'What, if anything, do you think would improve this training course?'

This only allows the respondent to select one response. Each response option must be mutually exclusive. That means, only one response option should be applicable to the respondent (so two or more response options must not apply)

This is where you allow respondents to select multiple response options. For example, if asking respondents about where they do their food shopping, they may need to select more than one option as they may go to different food shops.

The target responses for this question should exist in a form that can be rated.​

You should limit the number of response options when including a ranked question. This is because too many response options:​

  • can be confusing  ​

  • generate lots of data​

  • is burdensome for the respondent

A survey scale represents a set of answer options - either numeric or verbal -that cover a range of opinions on a topic. It’s always part of a closed-ended question. ​

Likert scales are widely used to measure attitudes and opinions with a greater degree of nuance than a simple 'yes' or 'no' question. They are a 5 or 7-point scale and are sometimes referred to as a satisfaction scale. The scale ranges from one extreme attitude to another. The Likert scale should have a neutral option, for example, a 'neither agree not disagree' or 'neutral'. Likert scales can give you more granular detail, which can help you to distinguish between whether something was just 'good' or 'excellent', for example.

A Matrix question is a closed-ended question that asks respondents to evaluate one or more row items using the same set of column choices. They are often overused but are attractive if all the questions use the same scale (as this prevents repetition). There are limitations to consider when using a matrix, such as:​

  • they can be tiresome to complete if there are lots of rows​

  • they can be difficult to read (especially from an accessibility point of view)​

  • they are open to satisficing (where the respondent takes short-cuts to make the process faster, meaning they don’t put much effort into answering the question)​

  • they are not good for mobile presentation (as this often requires lots of scrolling up and down and across the screen)​

  • it hides how long the survey is

Dropdown is a closed-ended question that allows respondents to choose one answer choice from a list of choices presented in a dropdown menu in a dropdown menu. They are beneficial when you have lots of response options and are easy to analyse as only one choice is allowed. However, you should try to limit the number of options you have as long lists can be hard to navigate.  You could allow for ‘type and reveal’ (where the respondent can start typing the response option rather than scrolling down the dropdown list), but this can be frustrating if the respondent isn’t wording it in the same way as the list.

This is where the respondent is allowed to type in a number. This type of question may require guidance on how to complete, for example, ‘round your answer to the nearest pound’. Consider:​

  • rounding​

  • decimal places​

  • estimates​

  • issue of units used £000’s, millions

title: New Component Title
body: You should adhere to the following question design principles and best practice when designing your questions:

_items.title: Key principles
_items.body:
The main areas you need to consider when designing your questions are:​

  • instructions – consider the wording of your instructions (for both overall survey and question specific instructions)​

  • question construction – how to word and structure your question, and what response option fits best​

  • order and flow – will the order of the questions affect the way in which the respondent answers? Does the overall questionnaire flow?​

  • navigational path – do all respondents need to answer all questions? Consider the route you will take them through the questionnaire​

  • respondent task – consider the difficulty of the question you are asking them​

  • visual design principles – for example, ensuring colours are used appropriately and consistently, ensuring how things are grouped on the page isn't then misleading etc. Find out more about visual design principles​

  • accessibility – ensure you are developing in line with accessibility standards

_items.title: Questionnaire design best practice - response burden
_items.body:
When designing your questions (and overall questionnaires), you should be minimising the respondent burden where possible. 

The Encyclopedia of Survey Research Methods defines respondent burden as: “The degree to which a survey respondent perceives participation in a survey research project as difficult, time consuming, or emotionally stressful is known as respondent burden. Interview length, cognitive complexity of the task, required respondent effort, frequency of being interviewed, and the stress of psychologically invasive questions all can contribute to respondent burden in survey research.”​

Respondent burden can affect response quality, so it's important to take measures to minimise this. ​

The concept of response burden can be divided into actual and perceived burden.​

There are four factors that constitute perceived respondent burden:​

  • frequency of contact​

  • length of contact​

  • required respondent effort​

  • stress of disturbing questions​

Burden should be considered from the very beginning of your research, and continuously throughout its development. ​

More information on respondent burden can be found on the Analysis Function wesbite.

_items.title: Questionnaire design best practice - wording
_items.body:
Keep questions and any wording in your questionnaire as short and simple as possible. Bear in mind the average adult literacy age is 9​.

  • Consider that the respondent may not have high numeracy levels, or that English may not be their first language​.

  • Avoid abbreviations (unless written in full previously), jargon and difficult concepts. Beware of terms that could be subjective, for example, the term 'regular'​.

  • Provide instructions where appropriate – but again, keep these short and simple.

_items.title: Questionnaire design best practice - layout
_items.body:
Ensure that the layout of your questions (and overall questionnaire) is clear and consistent.

Think about the ordering of questions – ensure you're not asking respondents to jump around between different topics – instead, it may be better to ask all questions relating to topic 1, and then move on to questions on topic 2, and so on. ​

Consider whether previous questions could influence the response to the current question.

_items.title: A few 'best practice' tips...
_items.body:
You should:

  • avoid leading questions – such as, 'would you prefer to live in the beautiful countryside or cramped inner city?'​

  • avoid double-barrelled questions (these are,, questions that are asking multiple things) – such as, 'do you exercise and eat well?'​

  • avoid double negatives – such as, 'don't you disagree that junk food is bad for you?'

  • beware of asking for information about proxies. Proxies refers to asking a respondent information about another person  - such as, 'how many hours did your husband work last week?'​

  • avoid unnecessary calculation that might include several mental steps – instead, break the question up into multiple questions to reduce burden​

  • where necessary, specify any time reference period – rather than leaving it vague, or not giving a reference period at all, consider including timeframes such as 'in the last 7 days' or 'over the past 12 months'​

  • consider whether you need to include a time reference period in your question stem as attitudes, behaviours, opinions etc change over time

title: New Component Title
displayTitle: The stages of questionnaire design, continued...

_items.title: 4. Consider whether you need an expert review
_items.body:
An expert review is where experts use their knowledge and experience to evaluate a product or service (such as, a survey). ​The reviewer should have a deep knowledge of usability and methodological best practices. They should also have past experience of conducting usability research.​

The reviewer should not be involved in the design of the product or service as having a new perspective is more likely to be unbiased. The reviewer will provide recommendations for changes and identify any areas that need further testing.​

When is expert review appropriate (or not)?​

If you are working in a multi-disciplinary team, with different experts working on the design of your survey (or data collection tool), it's unlikely that you will need to conduct an expert review. If, however, you aren't working in a multi-disciplinary team, or not many different experts have contributed or already reviewed your survey (or data collection tool), then you should consider an expert review. Expert review can be done before or after any pre-testing, however we would recommend conducting your expert review prior to the testing to maximise the value of the testing. ​

What is involved in an expert review?​

The expert review will start by considering existing survey questions and layout to determine any obvious areas that can be corrected. ​

Paradata can also be used to evaluate data quality and the respondent experience. Paradata = data about the process by which the data were collected (for example, Google Analytics). ​

By using paradata, it is possible to review the time a question takes to complete. If, for example, a question had a long completion time, you could make the inference that the question is causing confusion and/ or is difficult to answer. Or if there was high switching between the available response options, it could indicate that the options are ambiguous and respondents are unsure on which to select.

_items.title: 5. Test your questions - Cognitive Interviewing
_items.body:
Once you have designed your questions, you should test them using cognitive interviewing. ​

Cognitive interviews are one-to-one sessions with a participant and a researcher. The participant completes survey questions that the researcher has previously designed. The purpose of the interview is to evaluate the quality and comprehension of the designed questions.​

Cognitive interviewing is an example of when qualitative research can be used to support quantitative research. It’s popular for evaluating survey questions (a quantitative research method) and aims to study the ways in which individuals mentally process and respond to survey questions.​

Cognitive interviewing can increase the understanding of question validity (the extent to which your questionnaire measures what it purports to measure) and response error (the return of false or subjectively modified information from survey respondents). It does this by tapping into participants’ mental models, learning about their thought process, how they arrive at their answer, and so on.​

It is commonly used to pre-test questions within a survey questionnaire, to identify how they should be modified (if it all). In this case, the testing would occur before the survey has gone ‘live’. However, it can also be used for a survey questionnaire that already exists, in order to modify it for the next wave (I.e. the next administration of the survey), for example. 

 

'Think aloud'

A common technique used in cognitive interviewing is encouraging the participant to ‘think aloud’. This means, verbalising their thoughts and processes as they answer questions or interact with a service.​

Think aloud example:​

Let’s say I was asked a question about “how many windows are there in my house”. ​

If I was thinking out loud, I would say “ ...well, there’s one window in the kitchen…and then in the main room, there are two windows ... (etc.)” ​

Now, let me ask you the same question: “Think about how many windows there are in your house. As you count up the windows, tell me what you are seeing and thinking about.”

 

Probing questions

You can use probing questions to get the detail you need from them. Probes are used to target specific processes such as: ​

  • comprehension, that is, their understanding of the question and the words within the question - ‘What does the term [x] mean to you?’​

  • recall – ‘How did you remember that?’​

  • judgement – ‘How sure are you about that?’​

  • response – ‘How did you choose an answer for that?​

You can also ask the interviewee more general questions such as: ‘Can you tell me more about that?’​

 

When developing questions it's important to consider, and allow time for cognitive interviewing. This will ensure your questions are measuring what's intended, and ultimately improve both the data quality and respondent experience. ​

Cognitive interviews collect qualitative data. Use qualitative analysis techniques to analyse the data. You will use the findings from this analysis to reiterate and refine your survey questions. You can use the 'In person qualitative testing checklist template' and the 'Online qualitative testing checklist template'  to help you plan your cognitive interviewing.

_items.title: 6. Item and survey redevelopment
_items.body:
Questionnaire design is an iterative process - once the survey has gone through review, design and testing, any issues revealed are recommended for change and the process run through end-to-end again to determine if all issues are then corrected. These waves of testing will continue until either all the ‘major’ issues are resolved, or time runs out to test.​

You will then go Live with the survey, ensuring continuous improvement throughout its lifecycle.

title: Summary of questionnaire design
body:
• Establish any customer requirements before designing your data collection activities – clarifying concepts and definitions will help with this​.

  • Adopt best practice when designing your questions – e.g. are they leading, unbalanced or burdensome for the respondent?​

  • Consider the format of the response – do you need to gather in-depth insights and therefore need a free text box? Would including a pre-defined list of responses make the process easier or more difficult for respondents to answer the question?​

  • Whether or not you choose an appropriate question format, and associated response format, will all affect the quality of the data you get from your survey responses.​

  • Test your questions - this allows you to refine them before going live with the survey.

title: New Component Title
body:
The words ‘methods’ and ‘modes’ are used interchangeably. But we can distinguish between two main collection methods: interviewer-administered and self-administered (or self-completion). Note that by ‘interviewer’ we include staff in non-survey settings who are collecting data by means of a structured questionnaire or form. Similarly, by ‘respondent’ we include users of a service who are being asked a structured questionnaire or form. For each method there are various specific modes available.  ​

 We can also use more than one method or mode in the same survey, for example, in a mixed-mode design. We’ll look at that later in the module, but first we’ll consider each specific mode - their features and the advantages and disadvantages of using them.

_items.title: Interviewer-administered modes
_items.body:
Includes: 

  • face-to-face (in person) ​

  • telephone​

  • video interviewing (an emerging hybrid of face-to-face and telephone)

Interviewer-administration involves an interviewer reading out questions from a scripted questionnaire and recording the respondent’s answers. These days, computer-assisted methods (such as using a tablet or laptop) are the norm, although paper questionnaires are still an option. Interviews may be conducted in various locations as relevant to the study, such as: respondents’ homes, workplaces, in the street or other public spaces (for example airports and seaports for passenger surveys). The interviewer does more than just the questioning, for example, they may answer any questions the respondent has about specific question wording, or the respondent may ask a question about the survey itself.

_items.title: Self-completion modes
_items.body:
Includes: 

  • paper questionnaires (can be distributed by post or given in person)​

  • online questionnaires (can be distributed by posting information about the web address, emailing a link, or sending a web link by SMS) ​

  • offline questionnaires (a questionnaire file is sent by email attachment, or can be downloaded from a website, and returned to the host by email or by uploading it.  ​

  • telephone - Telephone Data Entry, or ‘TDE’ (the respondent dials in and enters responses using the phone keypad) or Interactive Voice Response (the respondent speaks the responses). ​Telephone modes are becoming more rarely used.

 Self-completion involves the respondent reading the questions for themselves and recording their answers into the online or paper questionnaire – or inputting their responses via the telephone. Where and when they complete the survey is at their choice. Ways to substitute the other tasks performed by interviewers have to be provided.

title: Deciding which method and mode to use
displayTitle: Deciding which method and mode to use
body:
We will now look at the pros and cons of the different methods that can be used. ​Selecting a method to use will depend on the context and nature of the survey.​ There will always be drawbacks no matter which method is selected, so a cost/ benefit analysis is needed. ​

Question: Think about the considerations for a survey commissioner, manager or designer when deciding which mode to use? What factors might impact on the survey’s data quality? ​

 

Main Considerations ​

Some of the considerations will be practical or logistical, while others relate to aspects of data quality. The interrelationship between them is where the cost/ benefit analysis is needed. Considerations include:

_items.title: Survey cost
_items.body:
In simple terms face-to-face interviewing is more expensive than telephone interviewing, and self-completion methods are cheaper than both. This is because interviewers can be expensive – they need paying, training, equipment, and where necessary, travel costs and managerial staff. ​

If you’re running a survey that is only intended to be used by certain parts of society (for example, a survey will only be sent to some households in the UK - not all members of the public, like the Census would be) then you will need to consider the size of that target group. The required sample size is an important consideration. How large does your achieved sample need to be? What analyses, if any, will need to be carried out – do you need to look at subgroups, lower geographical levels? ​

We need to consider the ‘unit cost’ of each sample member (that is, the respondent), and the more general set-up and running costs, alongside whether the survey is a one-off or the organisation runs numerous surveys (where there can be benefits from existing infrastructure and economies of scale).

_items.title: Population coverage and sampling frames
_items.body:
For general population surveys, we don’t have a population register or comprehensive databases of landline, mobile phone numbers or email addresses, from which to draw representative, random-probability samples with which we can make contact with.  ​

Additionally, although internet, landline and mobile phone access levels are very high, there are people who don’t have, or don’t like to use, one or more of them. Those who do and don’t use them might differ in important characteristics. So, we have to be aware of potential bias in the coverage of sampling frames and the data collection modes we employ. ​

However, for all the modes we can use comprehensive address lists and send a letter to the residents (although we can’t address individuals directly the first time we make contact), inviting them to take part (and if a paper survey, send the questionnaire).  We can inform them in the letter that an interviewer will visit them, or provide a link to an online survey, or tell them how to request a phone interview. 

Postal and telephone call costs are the same wherever in the country the sampled units are, so samples can be wide reaching and unclustered. In face-to-face surveys, we can reduce interviewer time and travel costs by clustering samples (selecting areas, then addresses within them), but this can impact on the confidence intervals around the estimates.  ​

Sometimes we might be able to use the respondent pool from one survey as the sample source for another, in which case it is possible to contact individuals directly and use the less expensive modes in the follow-on survey, if appropriate. Much of what follows in this module applies primarily to the first approach made to sampled units, rather than to such follow ups. ​

The sampling method used will ultimately impact on the cost of the survey.

_items.title: Response rates and non-response bias
_items.body:
In general, interviewer modes obtain higher response rates than self-completion modes. Face-to-face tends to gain a higher response rate than telephone. Response rates can be lower in self-completion modes.​

Well-designed respondent communications (letters, leaflets and - if we have the contact details - emails, phone calls etc) are necessary in any mode to inform sample members of the study details and why their participation is important. However, we can’t rely on them – either because recipients don’t read or pay close attention to them, or because they don’t perceive the survey to be important to them. Some population groups might be less motivated or able to participate than others, leading to less representative data.  ​

This issue can perhaps be more easily addressed by interviewers. They can persuade (but not coerce!) respondents to take part, answer queries and concerns, and avoid problems people might have in being able to self-complete the questionnaire (such as, language, literacy or cognitive issues). ​

However, interviewers may find it difficult to make contact with the residents, for various reasons, in a way that applies less to self-completion. The need for repeated calls at an address will increase costs.

_items.title: In-address or in-household response management
_items.body:
Survey outputs may be required at the household-level, rather than address-based – but some addresses contain more than one household which could potentially cause issues. Surveys can also vary as to whether they collect data about all the household members, or one household member only. There may also be an issue if someone responds to the survey on behalf of someone else (proxy data), as the information may not be accurate.​

 Interviewer involvement can make it easier to accurately identify and select households within an address, and individuals within a household. It provides more control over who answers the questions, which can be important if collecting data from within multi-person households.

_items.title: Survey field work and processing
_items.body:
The length of the fieldwork period may need to be longer for face-to-face interviewing than for telephone, where more interviews can be conducted in the same length of time. Self-completion modes can be slow to collect all responses, as respondents complete and return in their own time, and may need reminders.  ​

A field force of interviewers requires management, which can be a greater and more costly task for more dispersed face-to-face interviewers than for a centrally-located telephone force. ​

In computerised modes – whether face-to-face, telephone or online – return of data from the field to the centre will be faster than for paper/postal modes, and require less processing (data entry/scanning, coding and editing, data cleaning).

_items.title: Question administration and measurement error
_items.body:
There are a number of things to consider relating to the questionnaire itself and potential sources of error that can arise in the data.  ​

Questionnaire length: while we should always consider the burden on respondents and aim to keep the length as short as possible, regardless of mode, it is generally the case that face-to-face questionnaires can be longer than telephone and self-completion questionnaires. Interviewers can build rapport, and motivate and assist respondents, who are less likely to break-off than in self-completion modes if they find the survey burdensome or uninteresting.  ​

In interviews, there is more control over the question administration, for example:​

  • ensuring the questions are answered in the right order​

  • checking answers​

  • probing and helping with comprehension if necessary​

  • encouraging the provision of an answer, rather than a ‘don’t know’ or ‘prefer not to say’ if at all possible. ​

Interviewers will administer the questions appropriately and consistently, for example, reading the wording in full – whereas self-completion respondents might not all be so careful.

_items.title: Questionnaire complexity
_items.body:
Computer-assisted methods, whether interviewer- or self-administered, allow for greater complexity of questionnaires than paper methods. Here’s some examples as to why this is:​

  • complex routing between questions in an online survey could be hard for the respondent to follow if completing on paper. Routing refers to when a certain response to a question leads to the respondent being routed to, or away from, other questions in the questionnaire. For example, if the respondent answers they have no pets, they will be routed away from any questions that ask about the circumstances of their pet​

  • words and phrases within questions can be tailored to individuals, using answers from previous questions​

  • look-up coding frames can also be used (for example, lists of countries, or classifications such as occupation)

_items.title: Question types
_items.body:
Some types of questions are better suited to different modes. For example, open questions can obtain better quality data if administered by interviewers, who can probe if necessary to obtain the required nature and level of detail. ​

Questions about knowledge of a topic do not work so well in self-administered modes – the respondent could look up the answer or ask someone else.

title: Measurement error and mode effects
body:
Measurement error is the difference between a measured quantity and its true value. Measurement errors can be systematic (a consistent, repeatable error resulting from faulty equipment or poor design) or random (which affects your measurements in unpredictable ways, with no pattern).​

No mode is free from problems and sources of measurement error. But the problems and errors may differ in nature and likelihood between modes. Observed differences in data from different modes may not be real but due to how they are collected. The answers given to the same question by the same person might differ depending on which mode they are responding by. This feature is known as ‘mode effects’. ​

Question: What might be the nature of such difference between modes? What might cause them? 

 

Mode effects are caused by interactions between various features of modes, including:  ​

  • the presence or absence of an interviewer  ​

  • visual or audial presentation of questions  ​

  • the type of question (for example, factual, behavioural, attitudinal etc) ​

  • respondent ability (for example, literacy, numeracy, cognitive processes), interest and motivation ​

  • the task conditions and who is in control of the survey process (for example, location and environment, length of time required vs available) 

 

Satisficing and social desirability are common measurement errors when it comes to surveys. Click on each tile to reveal more information.

_items.backBody:
One of the main sources of measurement error which can differ between modes is ‘satisficing’. The respondent might not go through the response process (comprehension of the question, retrieval of information from memory, judging how what was retrieved maps onto the response format and providing the response) thoroughly. They might shortcut one or more stage in the process to provide an incomplete or inaccurate answer. Satisficing can be conscious or subconscious and vary in nature and degree. ​

​Factors that relate to satisficing include the task difficulty and cognitive burden; and the respondent’s ability and motivation. 

Types of satisficing include:​

  •  agreeing with opinion statements because it’s easier than thinking of why you might not​

  • answering ‘no opinion’ or ‘don’t know’​

  • choosing the midpoint on a scale​

  • not reading all the response options in a list but stopping when one seems appropriate, or, when listening to a list, not recalling the ones early in the list and choosing one of the more recent ones​

  • estimation, wild guesses or random answers.

This is when a respondent gives an answer which they think portrays them more favourably than the ‘real’ answer, by conforming to social norms or what they think the researcher, or another person present, would approve. It typically relates to sensitive topics, behaviours and opinions. ​

Social desirability bias tends to be higher in interviewer modes. In self-completion modes the respondent may feel more of a sense of privacy and anonymity. When comparing face-to-face and telephone modes, the picture is more complicated.  ​

Although the greater distance and lack of visual communication between a telephone interviewer and respondent might suggest a greater willingness to answer questions accurately, there is also less opportunity to convey the survey’s legitimacy, provide reassurance of confidentiality and build rapport than there is face-to-face. A mitigating option available in face-to-face interviews is to administer some questions by self-completion, either on paper or by handing the laptop/tablet to the respondent to read and answer questions themselves.

title: New Component Title
body:
Identifying mode effects can be hard...

Mode effects related to measurement error can be confounded (that is, mixed) with other mode effects.​

 If you observe differences between data collected by different modes, which of these factors is (or are) responsible? To what extent? And what is the impact on data: does it affect substantive conclusions? Which mode collects the ‘true’ data? It is difficult to measure and isolate the different effects, needing controlled experiments (which are often difficult and expensive) or other methods to control for non-response bias or tendency to respond. So many uncertainties remain. 

 

So which mode to choose?

An important thing to note is that no mode is error free. As we have explained, there are numerous factors to consider when deciding on the mode to use in your survey. We can do a lot with the design to reduce or mitigate the risks of the issues identified occurring. However, it is not be possible to avoid them all, so there is a need to weigh up the relative importance and likelihood of practical/logistical and methodological issues occurring, the impacts on costs and data quality, and make the choice on a cost-benefit analysis basis.

title: Mixed-modes
body:
To address the issues we have identified, increasingly, surveys are employing mixed-mode designs. That is, they combine methods to take advantage of the strengths and compensate for the weaknesses of each method and reduce coverage, non-response, measurement and other errors. There are many ways in which modes can be mixed. A few of the common ones are different modes: ​

  • for members of the same sample at the same point in time (some will respond by one mode, others by another). This could be by offering concurrent choice (for example sending an invitation that includes details about how to access an online questionnaire and encloses a paper version) or a sequential design (for example, sending an invitation with only details of how to access the online version, then following up the non-responders after a time and offering one or more alternative modes) ​

  • at different time points for same respondent (for example at different waves of a longitudinal survey) ​

  • for the same respondent at one time point (for example using a self-completion mode for some questions within an otherwise interviewer administered survey) ​

  • for different populations / subgroups (for example international studies, where countries’ capabilities may vary) 

Below are some advantages and disadvantages of using a mixed modes approach, compared with a single mode approach. Note that this will depend on which modes are in the mix.

_items.title: Advantages of mixed-modes
_items.body:
• Potential for reduced costs
  • Reduced total survey error* (such as, improved response rates, less non-response bias** due to increasing the overall access)

*Total Survey Error refers to the accumulation of all errors that may arise in the design, collection, processing, and analysis of survey data

**Non-response bias can occur when subjects who refuse to take part in a study, or who drop out before the study can be completed, are systematically different from those who participate.

_items.title: Disadvantages of mixed-modes
_items.body:
• Logistics of managing a mixed-mode survey can be complex
  • Responses may be subject to mode effects unless the survey is well-designed

title: New Component Title
body:
Designing mixed-modes questionnaires...

We’ve described mode effects on measurement error that can cause differences in data collected by different methods. It is possible, however, to reduce these effects in the design of questionnaires. Essentially, we want to prompt respondents to go through the same cognitive response process, in each or all the modes being used. This may or may not mean that the question wording and format is identical. Questions could be ‘unimode’ (exactly the same in each mode) or be different in some way between modes (‘optimised’ for one or more mode, in some way), but provide equivalent stimulus. ​

The best way to achieve such equivalence is through respondent centred design, with research and testing. Ideally, develop the questions for all modes concurrently (taking an optimode* approach), rather than adapt existing questions designed for one mode for use in another.  It can take time to develop mixed mode questionnaires. However, it is the best way to maximise overall data quality and minimise mode effects. ​

 * Optimode means to design the respondent communications and the questionnaire optimally for each mode. For respondent materials this means tailoring content of letters depending on the mode of interview. For questionnaires this means optimising the design for each mode. Having a design that works optimally in the mode that it is being administered will reduce respondent burden as it will be tailored to their needs.

title: Summary of methods and modes
body:
• Surveys can be interviewer-administered or self-administered​.

  • The method used will inform the choice of mode. For example, if developing a self-administered survey, the mode of collection may be a paper or online questionnaire​.

  • The combination of different modes is called a mixed-mode design​.

  • The main factors to consider when selecting a data collection mode include: costs, time, personnel, characteristics of the target population, response rates, questions type, questionnaire complexity and control over the question administration​.

  • Also consider mode effects and measurement error when choosing your mode.

_graphic.alt: Graphic showing which testing can occur at which stage. When defining study objectives, you can assess survey feasibility. When you have developed your survey design, you can conduct feasibility testing (pre-testing). When you adjust the survey design, you can conduct a pilot survey. You will then adjust the survey design again, which is when you can do a dress rehearsal before the mainstage survey.

title: New Component Title
body:
In practice:​

  • you would only need all of these stages for a new and complex survey that had not been run before or a survey that was being radically redesigned​

  • the more perceived ‘risk’ there is the more testing you might want to complete​

  • the ‘assess survey feasibility’ stage might be run by the analysis area prior to the survey being commissioned, as often this requires only desk research of potential designs and costs. The three items in red text identify potential stages of quantitative testing​

For a continuous survey that was making an annual round of questionnaire changes, you might only run a dress rehearsal (and probably only if the changes were fairly substantial or the survey was very important). For example, ONS usually run a dress rehearsal on annual questionnaire changes on the Labour Force Survey.​

For a complicated new survey you might run all of these stages – for example this approach was used for both the Wealth and Assets Survey and Life Opportunities Survey that ONS developed from scratch from the mid-2000s.​

We will now talk cover these three quantitative stages in turn.

_items.title: Feasibility testing (pre-testing)
_items.body:
Feasibility testing is a smaller version of a full-scale evaluation study. The main purpose is to test the most important assumption that a survey can answer the research questions identified. ​

You may not always need to conduct feasibility testing – there may be enough evidence in the research literature to make it unnecessary​

An initial feasibility assessment might result in:​

  • defined research questions to be answered​

  • the conclusion that a survey is a good way of answering them ​

  • defined options for the design of the survey​​

Feasibility testing could:​

  • aim to further develop the proposed survey design​

  • typically be commissioned as separately from the survey​

  • involve assessment by researchers, clients, expert interviewers​

  • be used to refine the specification for commissioning purposes

 

Typical feasibility testing approach

  • This would be a small data collection exercise with purposively selected a sample of around 10-100 respondents. By purposively selected we mean based on convenience, for example where you have interviewers available at the time​.

  • The nature of selection and small sample size limits the analysis possible​.

  • Data analysis can look at things such as item non-response (when respondents either don’t respond to a certain question, or don’t provide enough information for the response to be deemed usable) and interview lengths​.

  • You can only ever get indicative quantitative measures, but this can be complemented by qualitative information, for example, feedback from interviewers and respondents. This could be collected by questionnaires, but is usually more effective from face-to-face debriefings​.

  • The analysis of the testing would feed into a feasibility report. These are often published and can be provided to potential survey suppliers if the data collection is outsourced.​

  • If the survey is outsourced findings could also feed into the specification of requirements.

_items.title: Pilot surveys
_items.body:
A pilot survey is where the researcher sends out a questionnaire to a smaller sample size compared to the target audience. The sample should be representative of your target audience, but the sample should be random (that means, each person in the sample has an equal probability of being chosen). They are commonly used as they allow you to assess your entire questionnaire under survey conditions, allowing you to identify any problems before implementing the whole survey. ​

It's important to note that pilot surveys and dress rehearsals are two separate processes. Pilot surveys are more robust, formal quantitative testing approaches.​

The aims of testing tend to vary by survey, but typical aims include:​​

  • to estimate the likely response rate and response profile​​

  • more in-depth testing of the questionnaire function and data quality​​

  • to assess likely fieldwork costs​​

  • to give further indication of the quality of results (such as, sampling error for key measures)​​

  • to assess the impact of important methodological changes (such as, change in mode)​

​

Pilot survey outcomes: ​

  • pilot reports are typically focused on the recommendations. The objective is to agree the final survey design prior to any dress rehearsal.​

  • if the conclusion of the pilot is that the survey should continue, then the subsequent redesign is based on the agreed changes. Any changes to the survey design after a pilot survey would be expected to be minimal​

 

Limitations of a pilot survey

  • They cannot be a substitute for other data collection instrument development activities​.

  • They cannot tell you whether respondents can understand your questions, are willing to answer your questions and are able to access the information they need to answer your questions. Cognitive interviewing or cogability testing would be required to provide this information (more on cogability testing later)​.

  • Although some information can be gleaned from pilot interviewers, this is no substitute for valuable respondent centred evidence from respondents themselves earlier in the development process.

_items.title: Dress rehearsal
_items.body:
To illustrate the difference between a pilot and a dress rehearsal, a survey dress rehearsal is like other ways in which that term is typically used, for example for a play. You want all of the roles involved in delivering the main survey involved in the dress rehearsal, using the materials, processes and systems you expect them to eventually use. The survey dress rehearsal is a test of the operation of the end-to-end survey design. They are typically done for large or very complex surveys, especially if they are new. ​

  • The focus is on refinement and efficiency of the operation to ensure smooth running when the survey is launched​.

  • Although the focus of analysis is more likely to be identifying refinements that might reduce cost​.

  • Like with pilot studies, randomness in the sample is important otherwise you do not have a proper rehearsal.​

​

You want the evaluation to identify factors that could be improved (such as training or guidance) to make the survey more efficient (for example by reducing the need for retraining or reducing calls to the support telephone line requesting extra guidance).​​

There should be minimal changes to design after a dress rehearsal – this is more about getting the operation of the survey right.

title: An example...
body: We will now go through an example of Redesigning a survey -  the Children’s Dental Health Survey (2013). The stages below are in order.

_items.title: Context of study
_items.body:
• The survey was commissioned by the Health and Social Care Information Centre (now known as NHS Digital)​.

  • It is a school based survey conducted every 10 years – therefore there is previous methodology to draw on​.

  • There were some challenging methodological changes for 2013 survey​.

  • The survey moved from opt-out parental consent for dental examination with 5 and 8 year olds (2003) to a written parental opt-in consent which was a legal requirement​.

  • It was understood that the change in method would cause drop in response rate and risk increasing non-response bias​.

  • Analysts wanted to compare 2013 data to 2003 data (if possible) but the main objective was to get enough examinations​.

  • A steering group was established to work on this project.

_items.title: Consent testing
_items.body:
• The survey letter, information leaflet and consent form were sent to parents from participating schools​.

  • Consent materials were both cognitively tested and quantitatively tested in parallel due to time constraints​.

  • The pilot was designed to achieve a good indication of the likely consent rate. Twenty-five participating primary schools were selected​.

  • The pilot parental consent rate was 60% compared to the target of 75%.​

  • Action was required!

_items.title: Changes then agreed for the main survey
_items.body:
1. Schools were asked to send the first pack to parents via the child’s book bag (pupil post)​

  2. Interviewers were trained to proactively ask school staff to help them maximise the consent rate​

  3. Wording of letters, leaflets and the consent form was simplified (with plain English and legal advice)​

  4. Parents were given a clear deadline for returning the form​

  5. Survey branded stickers and fridge magnets were included​

  6. A new easy read information leaflet was available to be sent with the first reminder for cases where the school indicated potentially poor parental English literacy​

  7. Interviewers were provided with better information on consent forms that had not been received in advance of the examining day​

A series of changes were agreed with the Steering Group and implemented very quickly – with the aim of addressing the remoteness of our relationship with the parents (we had to go via the schools because of data protection).​

Qualitative information from cognitive testing and interviewer feedback informed these recommendations. It was clear from the cognitive testing that our remoteness from parents meant that the process needed to be simplified wherever possible.​

Change number one was thought to be the most important measure because it implied advocation from the school for taking part in the survey.

_items.title: Outcome
_items.body:
•  The main survey achieved a 73% parental consent rate (+13% over test)​.

  • There was still bias in the data associated with the new consent process​.

  • However, were able to meet the achieved sample size requirements for analysis​.

  • The survey was delivered on time and on budget​.

This is a good example of where redesigning is needed when the design meets reality. The research team had not fully anticipated the impact of the lack of direct relationship with the parents who were giving the permission. Quantitative and qualitative testing in parallel gave the information needed to be able to make significant improvements.

title: Summary of quantitative testing approaches
body:
• Feasibility testing can be used to get an idea of whether your survey is achieving its aims​.

  • Pilot surveys can be used to test your questionnaire under survey conditions.

  • Dress rehearsals can be used to evaluate the operation of the survey​.

  • Each has its own advantages and limitations, but should both be considered when developing a survey, particularly those that are new and complex.

title: Test your knowledge
instruction: Which of the following question formats allows respondents to choose a response from a predetermined list?

_incorrect.final: Incorrect. Open-ended questions allow respondents to give an answer in their own words, rather than them choosing from a predetermined list.

title: New Component Title
instruction: Is the statement 'Breaking complex questions down into multiple questions can reduce respondent burden' true or false?

_feedback.correct: Correct! Whilst breaking complex questions into multiple questions may increase the overall length of the questionnaire, it makes it simpler for the respondent to answer each question, reducing respondent burden.

_incorrect.final: Incorrect. Whilst breaking complex questions into multiple questions may increase the overall length of the questionnaire, it makes it simpler for the respondent to answer each question, reducing respondent burden.
